description:
A solo dungeon delve game where you adventure through a series of printed dungeons with you hero with the aid of a pencil and a die.

Encounter monsters, obstacles, and collect coins. Venture far and deep in this solo dungeon delve, roll and write, adventure.

The basics:

Each book is unique, because:
Each page is randomly generated
Play wherever, whenever

Gameplay is simple but entertaining: you roll a 6-sided die to determine how far you'll move each turn. Then pick a direction, draw a line, and interact with anything on that line, be it a monster (ouch!) some treasure (nice!) or a teleporter (cool!).

Customize your character, roll your way through each floor, and get items at the shops sprinkled throughout the game. There's even a page in the back to track stats like how many times you died -- so if you die, don't worry! It's all part of the adventure.

-description from Kickstarter Campaign

A Simple yet strategic tile laying, pattern making competitive puzzle, for kids and adults alike. Be the first to arrange tiles in such a way that an unbroken line of your chosen color connects the outer tiles of the (three-by-three) grid. You will be placing, replacing, switching, rotating and blocking tiles during play. It is a puzzle to solve and a race to solve it first.

Gameplay

Players take turns placing tiles on an imaginary invisible grid of three by three (3x3) with the goal of connecting the lines on the tiles. You want to connect the lines of your color around the outer edge of this imaginary grid. And at the same time preventing your opponent from connecting theirs.

As you place a tile, if there are tiles on the table, you must place it adjacent to another tile, horizontally or vertically. As soon as there are three tiles in a row or column, this sets the outer limits. The end result should be a three-by-three square of tiles.

As you play, you could do other actions instead of placing a tile, like rotating a tile, switching place between two tiles or replacing a tile. In addition to these four actions (placing, replacing, rotating and switching) you may always lock a tile at the end of your turn. You do this by placing your player marker onto the tile in question.

The winner is the first to have an unbroken line of their color connecting all of the outer tiles of the grid.

-description from designer

In this fast moving 2-4 player tile game you compete to complete large triangular 'frames' using four smaller triangular tiles to score.

Each triangular tile has a number in each corner (1, 2 or 3). The corners of the four tiles must match each other when they go into the large frame.

A players turn consists of two parts: completing frame(s) and scoring.

To complete their frames, a player either 'draws' two facedown tiles from the tilepile or 'swipes' one faceup tile from another players uncompleted frames. A swiped tile gets a 'swipe token' put on it to keep it from being swiped by another player. Each player only has two swipe tokens to work with, so be judicious on the swiping.

Scoring is done once a frame has all four tiles placed in it. That makes it 'complete', and the tiles become un-swipe-able. The player moves their completed frame to the center of the table to corner match with other frames already in the center. The numbers in the center of the matched edge do not need to match, but there is a bonus if they do. Once a frame is moved to the center, any swipe pawns are retrieved by the player to be used again later.

The game is over at the end of the turn when the tilepile is emptied. Each player subtracts one point for every tile infront of them in uncompleted frames. High score wins.

Strategy hints:
Generally it is better to draw than swipe unless you are completing a frame.

If you are way ahead on points, it is better to draw down the tilepile to bring the game to an end.

Frames are scored on the corner numbers, so when possible put your higher numbers in the corner of the frame.

Always be building your frames with an eye on the frames in the center of the table. It does you no good to complete a frame if there is no place to put it and score.

There are six of each of the eleven unique tiles. Towards the end of the game you can look around to see whether the tile you really need is still in the tilepile, or whether you need to swipe it from another player.

-description from designer

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with mental exercises. The backside of each card contains the solutions. Solve the exercises first and get the card. Player with the most cards at the end of the game wins the game.

This edition contains 150 questions about bizarre facts that are as useless as they are entertaining.

The title translates to "Useless Knowledge".

The successful mystery series "Black Stories" is also available in the "scary-free" version - for families with children from 8 years old. Instead of dark and scary it gets colorful and funny at the "Black Stories Junior".

Black Stories Junior: Detective Stories are exciting and tricky riddles for clever detectives. The players try to reconstruct the stories by asking, guessing and fiddling about.

Tac-Tik is a board game similar to Pachisi or Tock. It is most popular in France.

Players have to race their four wooden pawns around the game board to be the first to finish getting them all home. Movement of the pawns is determined by dealt cards instead of by dice. Each turn, players can play a card, and the value of this card determines how can they move their pawns. Some cards have special effects (1 or 10 can be used to place a new pawn into play).

King of the Pitch is a football board game played with boards, cards, cubes, chips and dice.

Every team will have a board with eleven white players corresponding to the lower level. In one action a team can get players to improve their level team, exchange cards or cubes to increase their money or play a game in the central stadium.

The box will become the stadium and the two teams playing in a game will have their suporters in it. Teams will roll the dice (the number of dice will depend on their level) to determine the winner of the games. Win or go home! if you win you stay and add a victory to your board.

First team getting five win will be crown as the "King of the Pitch".

Before the birth of time itself, great abyssals patrolled the darkness, guarding the secrets of the unborn cosmos. Infernals held court in their fantastic ballrooms, connoisseurs of decadence and indulgence. And most unfathomable of all, the celestials shaped, guided, created and molded.

In Primordial Secrets, players must send their obedient pawns to entreat these all-powerful titans for their aid and guidance, all while playing a strange and dangerous game of flamboyant intrigue. If a player's visitors have enough devotion, they will return with strong new allies, and with enough insight they could even uncover a dark secret guarded by a rival. Meanwhile, your deceitful hosts will try to lure the emissaries and party guests sent by your opponents to your sacrificial altar.

The game ends when a player has collected six sacrifices or stolen six secrets, and the unborn universe shall be theirs alone to rule.

—description from the publisher

The plane crash of the notorious archaeologist Dr. Hanz, alongside all of his research, has been discovered. Your mission: retrace his steps to uncover what happened to the sacred Idol of Kapookan. Explore the surrounding areas and venture through the caves of Mount Kap to uncover all the secrets, mysteries, and solve the many puzzles left behind by the ancient Mayan people.

Using the items found in the Mission: Maya game box, you'll need to solve all the puzzles you come across during your journey. Every card you flip will be a new area to discover, a new item to decipher, or perhaps a trap that ends up wasting your precious time. Solve all the puzzles and challenges to unlock the Lockbox and discover the Mystery inside.

When you find a secret code or have the solution to a puzzle, you can enter it into the Code Input on the Game Page. If you get the correct answer, a message will pop up with further instructions.

Components:
70 Illustrated Playing Cards
Dr. Hanz's Notebook
Dr. Hanz's Business Card
Polaroid
Envelope with 24 Puzzle Pieces
Burlap Pouch
8 Coloured Stones
6 Shattered Pieces
5 Mayan Coins
Scroll
Locked Box
Mystery Item

Who doesn't like cloud spotting?

In THE NEXT THING, playing stones represent clouds. Players take turns adding them to the board, and try to match the resulting combination to one of the displayed patterns.

As a player realizes that one of the patterns is going to be matched soon, they can bet on it. When a pattern is completed, the bets are revealed and those who predicted it first get a reward.

The game is over when all 7 stones from the prize pile have been taken or when one of the players runs out of stones. The player with the greatest number of stones wins the game.

In THE NEXT THING you will need to use both your social and pattern recognition skills to guess what other players are betting on, and your wits to outsmart them.

It is a fun, fast-paced game with a very simple rule set yet surprisingly complex strategies, suitable for both kids and adults.

-description from designer

Pandemic: Hot Zone – Europe features the same nail-biting co-operative experience of Pandemic in which players win or lose together, but in a smaller form that you can take anywhere and play in a shorter amount of time. As members of an elite team, you use your character's unique abilities to treat cases, stop outbreaks, and research the cures. Discover all three cures in time to win! Add extra challenges with new mutation cards!

—description from the publisher

In Cover Your Asps, players navigate the newly discovered Egyptian temple of Ombi Quadi to collect the treasures hidden within its inner chamber.

Cobra-like snakes called asps are the guardians of the temple. Asps are ready to attack from myriad snake pits. These pits are surrounded by quicksand, which is impenetrable by foot.

Use planks to build platforms to cover the quicksand and pits and get to the inner chamber. Navigate your pathways around granite slabs that raise and lower to block your path.

Reach the center of the temple and escape with a valuable treasure, but beware of the scorpion which your opponent will unleash. Play in rounds until all treasures have been recovered. Each round has three phases:
Build, Collect, Escape.

Four antechambers allow up to four players to compete against each other.

Configurable game board for a variety of challenge levels.

—description from the publisher

Ð¡Ð°Ð¼Ð°Ñ€Ð° ÐœÐ¾Ð½Ð¾Ð¿Ð¾Ð»Ð¸Ñ, Monopoly Samara is a local version of Monopoly set in the city of Samara. 
Players acquire cultural, industrial, entertainment and sports facilities and raise rents through upgrades. 
Own the Progress RKC, the Zhigulevsky brewery, the Rossiya confectionery, the Skat shopping and entertainment center and even the Kirovsky market. 
It includes 60 bonus and penalty cards (lottery, bank, authorities) ironically reflecting the city explicit and hidden economic processes.
Try not to go bankrupt while fixing all the roads!

In Universal Elements, two or more players race against each other to forge our solar system by combining the five basic elements (Water, Air, Fire, Earth, and Dark). The first player(s) to forge all celestial bodies on a Star Map wins.

After each round of forging, players are affected by a new Chaos card.  There's no telling what's out there! Often helping players that are behind, these Chaos cards keep the game interesting for beginners and experienced players alike.

This game is good for sharpening memory and dynamic math skills.  The space theme is consistent throughout, and conveys a wealth of space knowledge through play.

—description from the publisher

A long time ago, many shooting stars fell to earth.  Most of them fell upon a hill.  It was eventually named the "Starry Hill". The faithful built places of worship upon this hill and gathered the falling stone gems.  In present time you try to gather the gems also to collect resources and build your buildings.  The person that is the most successful wins.

On your turn:
You will have 1 dice, then you predict the color and number of the next dice you will draw from the bag.  Then assign your worker on the board. After drawing the die add the 2 numbers together if your prediction is accurate you will gain extra resources.

The game uses number prediction statistics, as well as worker placement.

After a greenhorn foolishly drops their golden nuggets on the saloon floor, the two players in Loot, Shoot, Whisky are caught up in a struggle over the precious loot.

Each round, four saloon cards are revealed, with the cards showing either gold nuggets, whiskey, or a bullet. Each player has a hand six cards: two each of Loot (go for the card), Shoot (take a shot at their opponent), and Whiskey (grab the whiskey bottle). Players each secretly play one card on the two saloon cards closest to the deck, reveal and resolve those cards, then secret play on the next two saloon cards, resolve those, then refill the saloon layout to four cards. The outcome of these confrontations uses a rock-paper-scissors mechanism:

• Whiskey beats Shoot, with the winner gaining a separate, non-saloon whiskey card or (if they already have it) flipping it over to "drink" it; if you win whiskey three times without the opponent taking back the bottle, then you finish the bottle and win.
• Shoot beats Loot, with the shooting player taking a hit card as a badge of honor. If you collect four hit cards, you win.
• Loot beats Whiskey, with the winner claiming the current saloon card. If this card is a shoot or whiskey, then you resolve those cards as described above; if this card shows gold nuggets, you collect those nuggets, and if you have collected nine or more nuggets, you win.

In case of a tie, discard the saloon card.

If someone doesn't win the game instantly as described above, then the game ends when you can't refill the saloon to four cards. In this case, whoever has the whiskey bottle on their side of the board wins.

American Pandemic is a hilarious party card game of survival when ordinary U.S. citizens face too much free time during quarantine.

Play as American neighbors competing for the most bad luck as a pandemic suddenly sends everyone into lockdown when the U.S. declares a national state of emergency.

Players must hoard and steal stereotypical American essentials from each other, overcome the endless awkward quarantine scenarios created from 2020 memes, and stop the impending world disasters by using the rarest, most valuable commodity of the pandemic… Toilet Paper.

Just like Americans competing over the worst 2020 story, players compete for bad luck points. Every round a Headline card is revealed as a new crisis strikes the American public. Each headline builds on the last - creating more and more bad luck for everyone. The only way to stop them… toilet paper, of course. Player turns are comprised of three phases: Escape, Hoard, and Quarantine.

Players begin their turns by drawing from the Escape Draw Pile to “escape” the active Headline cards. 
Players next must hoard as much as they can by drawing from the Hoard Draw Pile. Hoard cards include all the stereotypical American essentials needed to survive like toilet paper, frozen dinners, cbd gummies, essential oils, coffee, chocolate, wine, gloves, tv, computers, puppies, guns, masks, and much more.  Finally, players end their turn as they are forced into quarantine by drawing from the Quarantine Draw Pile. Inspired by the countless 2020 memes, players read out-loud the embarrassing and awkward scenarios while their opponents enjoy a good laugh at their expense.

Throughout the game, bad Luck is stored in a player’s Crazy Stash or Sick Stash. The Crazy Stash represents a player’s declining mental state while the Sick stash represents their failing health. The player with the most bad luck points at the end of the game wins.

-description from designer

No longer do you anxiously await the arrival of the wicked — for they have just arrived! In the dead of night, the gloom rolls in. Melodies whisper in slow rhythms as children wake from their slumber. Leaping from their beds, they rush to their parents and startle them awake. The mix of fear and excitement fills the room. The lure of exotic sweets wafts in on the warm summer wind. The lives of this dull, small town are revitalized with the anticipation of this dreadful circus.

Dreadful Circus is a set-collection card game in which players try to create the most successful circus! The game comes with an unique twist: Over the course of the game, players buy cards that have special final scoring rules. As the game progresses and more cards are gained, each player develops their very own final scoring rules. No game is the same, and no player at the table scores the same way.

—description from publisher

Eleven — the number of players you have on the pitch at any given time, with those players making all the difference between being the best team and the worst. But every team knows that to be the best in the league it takes a lot more than players; it also takes an incredible manager.

Eleven: Football Manager Board Game is an economic strategy game set in a world of sport. Your task is to manage and grow your own football club over the course of a season. During the game, you hire staff members, including trainers, physical therapists, PR specialists, and directors. You acquire sponsors, expand the stadium infrastructure, and take care of your club's position in social media. Among the many tasks on the list are transferring new players and choosing the right tactics for each of the upcoming matches.

Eleven can be played multiplayer or solo. The solo mode includes six different scenarios that challenge players with different starting situations and goals for the season. In the beginning, the task is simple: You have to climb the steps of the football leagues and achieve the appropriate experience. You may have to manage the club in a crisis, and at other times you will have to rejuvenate a football team of players that are not so young anymore. You may also have to fight against time to try to complete the stadium before the deadline!

—description from publisher

Ð“Ð¾ÑÐ¿Ð¾Ð´Ð¸Ð½ Ð’ÐµÐ»Ð¸ÐºÐ¾Ð³Ð¾ ÐÐ¾Ð²Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ("Lord Veliky Novgorod"), is a monopoly-type board game played on a map of Veliky Novgorod, divided into the main areas of the cities, with local businesses.

The goal of the game is to purchase land, then build and finally earn money from the rent.

The winner is the player who avoids bankruptcy.

RECREATE ITALY’S SOCIAL REVOLUTION (1861 - 1945)

As a powerful leader during Italy's tumultuous social revolution (1861-1946) wisely choose leaders, causes, and adapt to your opponent's tactics to win. Support Italy's King, Pope, and Prime Minister to gain control of a newly unified Italy. Devise clever strategies for creating your political, economic, and military power base. Grow your power by adding cities and their resources, appointing political leaders, and leading military attacks.

BUT BEWARE!

Enemies may implement their own military, political, or economic strategies to exploit your weaknesses. Allies may turn into enemies, deposing your leaders, instigating revolts in your cities, taking your income and might.

Kingdom of Italy realistically reenacts the turmoil and tactics from Italy’s past - bringing a totally new level of competitiveness to card games. Diplomacy, risk-taking, military planning, deception, and a sudden turn of fortune are all viable approaches for gaining the upper hand.

COURSE OF PLAY

Players seek to become the dominant faction in Italian politics and society through building and managing a tableau of allied Cities with attached Leaders, Military Forces, Spies, and Resources, represented by cards.  Players are each dealt a hand of cards and take turns playing Cities and attaching other cards to them as allowed, drawing additional cards at the end of each turn.  Players can potentially switch Cities' alliances through the influence of Leaders or seize them by force through military campaigns resolved through a combination of card and dice play.  The game ends once all cards are drawn.  The winner is determined based on total points scored in their tableau with different cards having different values.

ÐœÐ¾Ð½Ð¾Ð¿Ð¾Ð»Ð¸Ñ: ÐšÐ°Ð·Ð°Ð½ÑŒ, Monopoly Kazan is a local version of Monopoly set in the city of Kazan in the Russian Republic of Tatarstan.

To win in Tatarstan, like anywhere else, do not get bankrupted!

Focused on fighting it out in the confined battlegrounds of the Pariah Nexus, this expansion introduces new rules for close combat encounters in its claustrophobic depths. The box also features kill teams for the Space Marines and Necrons, both comprising brand new models. The Space Marines have sent a Captain with master-crafted heavy bolt rifle and five Heavy Intercessors to carry out this dangerous mission.

—description from the publisher

The objective of Squelettos is to collect a sequence of cards depicting skeletons and display them in ascending order and hopefully from the same family too, to gain bonus points.
Players take turns flipping over as many cards as they want from the central deck, to choose the one to keep.
But the player that turns over 2 cards of the same colour loses his turn and the chance to keep any card from that round at all.

—user summary

In Vulture Capital, you try to dump your junk assets into the open market. Taking cards is usually bad, so the object is to take as few cards as you can.

Players play several rounds, making blind bids that capture other cards, whether you want them or not! Each card you capture is one negative point (regardless of its rank) — unless you capture a full set (all the cards in one rank) in which case it's worth positive points equal to its rank.

The player with the highest score wins.

[Vulture Capital originally appeared as the "Venture" variant in PAIRS: Professor Elemental. Rights reverted back to the designer Daniel Solis.]

In this game of logic, the players position the ants side by side, but beware... it isn't always easy to find your way around this ants' nest...

The aim of the game is to get as many ants on the 9x9 garden board as possible.

The game:
The player on his/her turn places one card adhering to the following rules:
- The card must connect to an already played card, the ants must connect.
- The card should not cover an anthill.
- The card must fit within the 9x9 board.

Then it's the next player's turn.

If one player is unable to place a card, the other player can continue until none of the players can play a card.

At the end of the round the players count the squares of the cards in front of them that have not been played. The player with the lowest number of squares wins a "points won" card.

The first player to have won 3 "points won" cards wins the game.

Super Heroes vs, Villains in a Plus Ultra game experience that contains nearly 300 cards!

In My Hero Academia: League of Villains you must recruit super-powered Students and Heroes to your Agency. Select the best combinations of Quirks(super-powered abilities) to complete challenging Missions, defeat deadly Villains, save the world and become mightiest Agency around!

Welcome to Retro Game Jam. The annual pixel platformer design competition. Do you and your team have what it takes to design a retro game in under half an hour? well let's see you put your skills to the test!

In Pocket Pixel Artist, teams will compete against each other through a series of design challenges to see who can design and assemble the best pixel art graphics they can for a game jam submission! Against the clock, and only using small colored cubes, you must arrange them into 1 of 4 various game assets found on each card. (220 in total) if your team can correctly identify your creation you will gain points!

—description from the designer

Players divide into teams.

The team that goes first will choose easy, intermediate, or difficult rhymes. A member of the opposing team draws a card and reads a target word corresponding to the difficulty level chosen. A timer starts (when using the app this will include a musical beat) and the team has one minute to say as many phrases as they can that end with a word that rhymes with the target word.

Points are received based on how many rhymes the team came up with and the difficulty level of the word they chose. Some specifically difficult rhymes appear on the card as bonus points, but any rhyming word is acceptable, even words not listed.

Then it is the other team's turn to do the same. Each team plays four rounds, and then the team that has the most points will be the winners.

Contents:
135 Playing Cards (Easy, Intermediate and Intellectual)
1 Scoreboard
2 Playing Card Clips
1 Microphone
1 Dry Erase Marker
1 60-Second Sand Timer

As its predecessor, Genius Square, this is a race to fit blocks onto the board around a randomly generated configuration of obstacles. This time, the blocks are made of triangular cells, and the board is a six-sided star.

Roll the seven dice and place a ‘blocker’ piece into the triangle matching the seven numbers that appear on the faces. Now race your opponent to fill every other space on the grid using the 11 shapes.

A new feature of The Genius Star is a "double-win" bonus for forming the golden star icon while also completing the puzzle.

The publisher labels this "more challenging" than The Genius Square, citing 165,888 possible puzzles, 57.4% of which have a golden star solution.

The Game of Rescue is one of a trio of games from Chad Valley's Kompactum Edition, circa 1910.

A simple roll and move sees up to 4 players race from the sea shore to reach a floundering masted boat in rough sea. Along the way the rescue team can be hampered or favoured by landing on specific squares. First to reach the sinking vessel on square 30 is the winner.

The game probably came boxed with two other Chad Valley games being 'Aerial Derby' and 'Loco' as the long narrow board dimension is identical to Aerial Derby and exactly half that of Loco. The other two games are listed separate.

—user summary

The Game of Loco is one of a trio of games from Chad Valley's Kompactum Edition, circa 1910.

A simple roll and move sees players leave one of three railway stations in London and race through the English towns and countryside to finish in Edinburgh. Along the way the players can be hampered or favoured by landing on specific squares. First to reach Edinburgh is the winner.

The Kompactum Edition version of this game probably came boxed with two other Chad Valley games being 'Aerial Derby' and 'Rescue' as the board dimension is exactly double that of 'Aerial Derby' and 'Rescue. The other two games are listed separate.

—user summary

In Tree Hotel, each player tries to be the first to fill all the empty slots in his tree with guests. Some guests come voluntarily, others must be lured in with red berries, but beware of the insatiable racoon that steals all your red berries. And watch out for the grim brown bear that adores frightening single animals away from your hotel!

Game play: Place a Tree Hotel in front of each player. Shuffle the cards and place them face down, as common draw pile, in the middle of the table. Foresee some space for the common discard pile, the personal berry stashes, as well as the personal discard piles that will be generated during the game. Starting with the first player, you take turns clockwise. Draw the top card from the common draw pile, flip it over, and make sure everybody sees it.

Goal: Be the first to accommodate 3 pairs of animals in your Tree Hotel.

-description from publisher

The ship swings, the gold lies on the planks, and underneath the sharks are circling.

Gezanke auf der Planke is played on a real 3D ship that lies rocking in the waves. All pirates want to get as close as possible to the prey, but most of the coins can be found only on the most tricky plank sites on the ship's exterior. With each move, one of the six planks is pushed sideways over the deck, and a pirate on the ship is moved. This always puts some pirates out of balance...

—description from the publisher

At breakneck speed, all players simultaneously distribute their animal cards over seven areas. Because different animals are always in demand in each landscape, lightning fast re-thinking is required.

In more detail, each landscape of In Windes Eule has its own laws: In the harbor, only the first animal of each kind can come on board. In the clearing the presence of doubled animals is frowned upon. And in the villages, rats spread a plague that only cats can help against. Everywhere bats, hawks, and flying kites flutter in and over the castle — always ahead of the wind.

—description from the publisher

UMBRA is a science fiction map drawing game that tasks you with the unenviable task of starting a colony on a hostile alien planet. As the game progresses you will dig into the planet's core in search of an ancient weapon known as The Reaper's Gambit but be warned, no matter how dead a planet looks on the surface, there is always something awful lurking underneath.

Inspired by Rimworld, Startopia, and various sci-fi horrors like Alien, The Thing, Predator, but don't worry, for all the horror on display UMBRA lets you take the lead on what your colony will look like and what your story will be.

After choosing what kind of planet you land on, you explore by drawing a playing card to determine what you find on each turn, if there is combat, it's simple and turn based. After exploring, you can trade your resources and build your colony (rooms and security systems), then you can recruit new units. You also need to balance foond and power so your colony survives. You win by finding the Reaper's Gambit, a special alien weapon that might be saving your species.

Tiny Turbo Cars is a frantic race game for 2 to 4 players in which you program the movements of your tiny toy car in advance, with a sliding puzzle acting as your remote controller.

Choose your car, grab your remote controller, create the track, and get ready to race! At the beginning of each round, players have to work their way through their sliding puzzle controllers simultaneously, trying to create the sequence of actions they want their car to perform during the round.

Each symbol on the puzzle corresponds to one of the possible actions — but only the two middle rows of commands on your controllers will be applied, so there's room for maneuvers, but be quick! The first player to put down their controller will be the first to move their car during the round. Each player then executes the program they created, and the sooner you play during a round, the safer you are that your actions will actually play out as planned rather than crashing into unexpected obstacles...or other cars!

But trying to be quick might also increase your chances of making mistakes, and every time you take damage, you lose battery power, which will slow you down. But hey, mistakes happen, right? You can always recharge and be back in the race.

This is a fierce race, with pitfalls around every corner and unscrupulous adversaries! Don't miss your chance to shoot your missiles at your opponents — before they hit you! The first player to cross the finish line wins!

—description from publisher

Seven Fallen is a Fantasy fighting collectible card game from France. In the story of Sevenfall, there are 7 kingdoms fighting for domination of the world.  Initially released in 2020 under the name "Les 7 Royaumes".

You play as a Divinity and your goal is to destroy your opponent with your best army of Angels and Golems. The first goal of the game is to include the players into the process of rules creation and gameplay.

100% of the cards can be played and considered in a deckbuild. There are no vanilla cards.

—description from the publisher

The players start at the center and follow the spiral path around the game board. Movement is determined by a die. Along the way the players join the communist party, earn money and are promoted to general secretary. On some spaces the players have to draw cards that benefit or hinder the players. The first player to change his money into 50.000,- Deutsche Mark and defects to western Germany wins the game. Comrade, don't be cross!

—user summary

SOPWWID, a Solitaire One Page World War I Dogfight game has an extremely low footprint, minimal components, and simple rules.  The entire game fits on one piece of paper, front and back.  Also needed are 11 coins (1 penny, 5 dimes and 5 nickels or any other set of coins), and 1d10.  Alternately, you may print plane images (included) instead of using coins.

The goal is to shoot down as many enemy planes with your Sopwith Camel before being shot down yourself.

Each turn, you'll maneuver your Sopwith by selecting from 1 of 31 hex movement options.  Then the AI will maneuver each enemy plane (both Fokkers and Pfalzes) by a roll of a die.  Although random, the available movement options vary given the relative position of your Sopwith to the enemy.  As a result, the enemy AI is eerily accurate, meaning the enemy is quite effective at hunting you down.

Then every plane shoots in a straight hex row if it has an enemy in its sites.  Your Sopwith has a range of 4 hexes, the Fokkers may shoot 3 hexes, and the Pfalzes shoot 2.

Every plane is shot down on it's second hit.  Fokkers are worth 10 points, Pfalzes 5 points, and if your Sopwith is shot down, you are out.

If you survive the first wave of 1 Fokker and 1 Pfalz, each successive wave adds 1 additional Fokker and 1 additional Pfalz.  [The designers record is 55 points!]

A fast playing card game based on Rummy, with a deck of 1-8 number cards in 8 suits, each a different mythical creature, plus 6 wild Dragon cards.  Play a set or run of cards (meld) or play onto another meld. Score points for the number of cards you play - the multiplier decreases each round, so play as soon as you can for maximum points. The hard part is only being able to put cards in/on one meld each round. Buy the card you need by taking a penalty. Slap down a Wild to finish a meld or for extra points, but don't get stuck with one at the end!

Family friendly and a light game that can be played while waiting for takeaways or another game to finish.  Play with two packs to expand to 7-10 players!

—description from the designer

La Última Enfermera is a game about the "crazy" work that nurses usually have to do. At this game each player represents a nurse at a job center, and one day they are called to start a work at the hospital on a random medical field, where they have to fulfill tasks.

At the beginning of the game each player is given a secret Identity Card (each of them related to a different field where you can work at, and each of them of different colour).

A deck is then formed with all the other cards (Task, Situation, Character and Item cards) shuffled. Each turn the player on turn has to draw a new card from the deck, add it to his hand (unless it's a Situation card, in which case it's resolved inmediately. Usually it's an event which changes something on the game, like shuffling all Identity cards of the players and re-dealing at random), and finally has to play or discard one card from it's hand.


     Task cards can only be played (face down near the Identity card of that player) if it's a task of that type of work (it's of the same colour). If the card doesn't match your Identity card colour it has to be discarded.
     Characters and Items are played to make it's special action.


The first player to have 5 Task cards of it's colour wins the game.

Bone to Pick is a thrilling, fast paced semi-cooperative party game with multiple game modes. Battle against the undead in a Quick or Campaign game!
And if you want to "raise the bar" - try the Epic mode.

1668. The world as we knew it is gone. Millions of roaming undead have taken over most of 17th century Europe. You and a ragged band of survivors discovered an abandoned haven, a ghostly city with crumbling stone walls. You are few, low on supplies and an undead horde is drawing closer. You have to make your stand here it seems. Kill the abominations, gather their trophies, but also beware of your treacherous companions, or you will not survive the onslaught.

You’ll need the Weapon Decks and the Undead Deck for the Base Game. Before starting the game, draw 10 Undead Cards randomly; without knowing their order or strength; to create the Undead Deck and each player receives their own Weapon Deck of 12 cards.Each player places their card face down and turn them simultaneously.

The combined scores will tell whether you’ve lost the battle…
...or vanquished the enemy! The player who played the strongest Weapon Card can keep the defeated Undead Card as a trophy.

If your Haven has survived the onslaught, the next step is to sum up the strength of the remaining Weapon Cards and to add the value of the defeated Undead Cards Trophy Points player by player. The player with the highest score will become
the LEGEND.

If you have lost and your Haven was razed to the ground, sum up the strength of the remaining Weapon Cards. The player with the highest score will become
the SCAPEGOAT.

Campaign Mode enables players to fight the Undead in four waves, where each wave tis stronger than the previous one.
Players can upgrade their weapons after each wave and the best defenders will also gain extra rewards. At the end, if the Haven is still standing, the summed up scores of the four waves will determine the winner.

The game can be played up to 12 players with 2 core box.

-description from artist

Like the famous Kalah or bean game, Conference is a game for two. The game is played in the box with a casino made of velvet-covered plastic. The "beans" consist of 36 wooden discs that are embossed on one side with a coat of arms.

—user summary

The two games of skill "Jet" and "Boccia" are included. "Boccia" is the famous French national game "Boule" brought to the gaming table. The game is played with a plastic figure, one arm of which is movably attached to roll the ball across the fairway to the target ball. With "Jet" it is important to roll your balls with the throwing figure into fields with as many points as possible.

—user summary
20th Anniversary edition of Metro, with 6 new City Expansions - Berlin, London, New York, Paris, St Petersburg, and Stockholm.

A game of amazing curiosities and essential knowledge that will build on the well-known Trivia board games. A variety of questions await the player!

What are the things everyone needs to know about their homeland? Put yourself to the test with the enchanting Hungary quiz game, which guides you through cultures, from the best-known traditions and sayings to the most interesting facts, if you go through different topics!

Topics:

History
Culture
Science and nature
Geography
Sports
Mixed
Plant the whole family for a new, shared experience where everyone can learn something.
How much are you in the picture?

Everyone plays at once, so no one gets bored!
Multiple choice puzzles to make fun for everyone!

#Maradj otthon! ("Stay Home") is a simple and fast-paced party game that is great fun for all ages. The original game was created by Ms. Lenhardt Kwaysser Fatime, winner of the 2020 Super Teacher Award, during her quarantine for her own class, and was later further developed with the help of the Blue Game. The year 2020 has left us with a lot of bad feelings and memories, but it is important that we can laugh despite the difficulties.

The goal of the game, which can be played by 2-6 people, is to preserve our cold blood and overcome the obstacles in front of us in the constantly changing conditions. Collect all 19 points! During the game, they could step on a special game board that could change at any moment, creating a whole new situation for the players. When collecting points, don't forget about the mask and hand sanitizer! Funny quarantine cards will help or hinder us during our mission.

If we come together from time to time to defeat the virus together, we can also play with the semi-cooperative game mode: here too we collect points for ourselves, but in the meantime we also have to pay close attention to the threatening virus so that it does not outgrow us! We can only defeat it by working together together if we are willing to make sacrifices and give up the points we have already earned. In the game, we tried to smuggle a lot of humor in addition to the current problems, to solve the limitations and annoyances of everyday life.

Masks produced, have fun!

—description from the publisher (translated)

The Pratzen: Austerlitz, 1805 is a two-player Tactical level board-wargame that portrays the fighting on and around the Pratzen Heights at the Battle of Austerlitz. The battle was fought between the French forces of Napoleon Bonaparte and a larger allied army composed of Austrian and Russian forces. The battle is considered to be one of the most important and decisive engagements of the Napoleonic Wars. The engagement result brought the War of the Third Coalition to an end and about the Treaty of Pressburg. The battle is widely thought of as a tactical masterpiece on par with Cannae.

The game system of The Pratzen: Austerlitz, 1805 began some three decades ago as an idea to update the SPI Tactical wargame Grenadier, published in 1971. Pratzen evolved into a merger of the Grenadier scale with some different combat mechanics based on the original von Reisswitz Kriegsspiel rules of 1824, adopted as a training tool in the Prussian army after the Napoleonic Wars. The scale was shifted from half-battalions to companies and divisions as the basic infantry maneuver piece, and much additional streamlining and simplification ensued.

—description from the publisher

An exciting new game in which you collect electors, buy states and collect electoral votes to win the White House.

The game features intelligently designed board squares along with two types of cards.  VOTE cards are pulled at every turn, resulting in gain or loss of electors. MAGA cards have various social and political circumstances which affect your candidate.

The game rules intelligently integrate the game elements in a way that creates levels of decision making. This includes buy no buy decisions for states, strategy for dice rolls and decisions about swing states

The game includes funny plot twists like getting a “Rudy” card to avoid an indictment and creatively designed elector dollars festooned with electoral colleges members. Future plans include expansion packs for each election, including cards designed around the political social climate and events of that time.

—description from the publisher
